utterances.sentences: -- individuals -- it does. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- but my family lost their lives and their farms and fled to this country with a suitcase to escape communism.

utterances.speaker: HARF

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It's not her. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let's get Dan in here.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: They are not getting attention because we are obsessed with her.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Marie says other freshman members of Congress don't have 1.2 million followers on twitter and aren't on "60 Minutes".

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Why should that matter?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Because she is talking to 1.2 million --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's what elected Trump.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: -- as Kennedy said, impressionable people who actually believe confiscation the money of free citizens in the United States may work like that outrageous proposal to tax people. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BONGINO

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: But this is an economically illiterate, ridiculous proposal. I could not care less about AOC, Occasio-Cortez at all. I don't care about her dance videos in college.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I enjoyed that by the way.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: But I do care about is proposing an absurd socialist economic confiscation of our tax dollars that is going to destroy the U.S. economy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do you know what I like about her? She compared herself to Lincoln and FDR. utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know who else did that? Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You have to understand that the more that you obsessed or say something it, you Trumperize (ph) her. That's how Trump won.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She needs to make $10 billion first before she could become --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He sucked all the air out.

utterances.speaker: HARF

utterances.sentences: She'll probably give it all away though. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Could the shutdown last for years if Democrats don't agree to build the wall? What the president is saying, up next.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: President Trump standing firm on building the border wall. Good for him. And saying that while progress with lawmakers has been made to end the shutdown could go on for a long time.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We mentioned the price, that we want $5.6 billion, very strongly. This is national security we are talking about. We are not talking about games. We are talking about national security.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The shutdown could go on for months or even a year or longer. Did you say that and is that your --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I did. I did. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Is that your assessment of where we are?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I did say that. Having a border that makes sense without borders, I have said it many times. We don't have a country. I hope it doesn't go on even beyond a few more days.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: The president also saying he may declare a national emergency to build the wall without Congress. As for the Democrats, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is not budging on Trump's demands.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF., SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.sentences: We really cannot resolve this until we open up government and we made that very clear to the president. A wall is an immorality. It's not who we are as a nation. We are not doing a wall. Does anybody have any doubt that we are not doing a wall? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Kennedy, I know you and I have been spicy over this for the past few days, but walls are an immorality. Do you think there's any legitimacy to that absurd comment by Nancy Pelosi?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: No, and I wish people would push her on that and try and figure out exactly what she means when she says something like that. You can have disagreements about border security, but she is in a pretty powerful position now. She has re-ascended to the speakership. So, I would like to know from her that's fine. What is your vision of border security? What does that mean? You know, let's get away from the emotionalism for just a second because both sides are really stoking up their bases with this issue, which is what makes it less solvable. But if she believes that there should be border security and if she believes in the type of sovereignty that she has advertised in the past, then what does that mean? And she is now in a position where she has to spell it out. She is no longer a reactor. And it's much more fun to be the minority part of where you're just reacting to everything.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, she is in charge now.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: But that is not her role at this point. So, if she is going to take a lead on this, then tell us what you are going to do. Tell us how you're going to make people in Border States feel better about some of the vulnerabilities that they have concerns with. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: I agree. It's time for them to lay out a plan. But Marie, on this topic, they keep saying, you know, we don't need walls. We need technology for border security. I have been dying to ask someone on the other side, obviously you're going to give the other side's perspective on this. Can you explain to me in rational, sane terms for the rest of America what technology will do that a wall will not?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I think you need a combination of both physical and technology ways to secure the border and I think a lot of Democrats would say that. What the Democratic house did last night was pass a bill that would fund all of the government except for DHS, so except for the wall, would fund that through February to actually have that knock down drag-out fight. The Democrats will have to put forward what they see for border security. I think that's an imminently reasonable proposal. You can get those 800,000 people back to work. I will also say President Trump today kept saying that the government workers who are not getting paid support him. There is a new poll from GovExex of federal workers says 71 percent oppose the shutdown. So, these are people who are not getting paychecks. You know this, real life it's hard for many of these government employees without a paycheck. Also interesting that Mitch McConnell was not at that press conference today because it's the Senate that really holds the cards here. You have another Republican senator today saying we need to re-open the government without border wall funding. They are feeling the heat and the pressure. And if they cave and they send something to Trump, it really is on him then to veto it or to keep all of these people -- get them back to work.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: It's just quick. You don't believe walls don't work, right? You acknowledge they work.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I think a form of physical barrier is important.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: All right, nice. This is a start. You see, we are solving the crisis right here.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: We just solved it, Dan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think necessarily McConnell need to be out there in front of the cameras.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Well why wasn't he?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because they are only going to consider and vote on something that can get the president's signature. So it's a waste of time to have him negotiate. It's between Nancy and the president. On the issue of the government workers, here's why I think it doesn't favor Nancy Pelosi. When it comes to Trump, he has the upper hand here. The issue excites his base. The issue, the wall, is favorable to Republicans. The government has not imploded. The sky is not falling and the market doesn't really care. On the Pelosi side, most of the government workers are Democrats. Let's be honest. And they are not radical, open borders Democrats that are partisan people. They probably want a little border security, but what they want more are their paychecks. And if Nancy Pelosi is holding their paychecks hostage to score political points against Trump, I don't think that looks good. Also, life goes on when the government is shutdown. The myth is everything stops when the government shuts down. And to have that fantasy out there really exposes Democrats.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It's not 1996 anymore.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Greg, does it say something that we are paying $4 trillion dollars a year collectively as a society for this (inaudible) we call government. It's been partially shut down now for 12 days and largely it has had relatively little impact on any American's life?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Eight hundred thousand people.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: I am not talking about that. I'm talking about the people out there working --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would like to talk about this morning's "Morning Joe" because I saw something really delightful. Can we throw that up, please?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You have four white men. You have four stoic, strong white men of a certain age, not smiling by the way. And, you know, look, this is all Donald has left. He has one thing, this wall, it's not a wall. It is a -- let's keep America white again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, I just had -- there are a couple of things here. So, Donny Deutsch, they should reproduce him and link him together and put him on the border because he is thicker than most walls. That guy -- so what he did was he used the argument that the wall is emblematic of racism. So, the wall around the studio make the entire show racists. But as he is doing that, he points out the race of the men out there. Those three white bald guys. Who is the closet racist here?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Weren't they Hispanic? Wasn't one of them Hispanic?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: One of them was Hispanic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, one of them was Hispanic. I think he owes an apology to those men who try to keep this government -- this country safe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And why should they be smiling?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He is such a Deutsch bag.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Can I ask you one question though.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: So, it's obviously so hard to get this $5 billion. The wall as the president originally conceived of, is going to cost a lot more than that. So does that mean that we are going to come to an impasse and have a shutdown every time there is more money required to finish parts of the wall?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: I think it's about the principle. We've been told since Simpson (ph) was only under Reagan that we were going to get legitimate border security in exchange for all the stuff we never got and I think Donald Trump is doing what cowardly, spineless, jellyfish, gutless Republicans done enough (ph) has said for years.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: So let's say he gets the $5 billion now, which really is not that much considering how much it's going to cost.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: So what happens when he needs more?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Its $5 billion more than zero and we have to fight the fights in front of us. The fight in front of us now is to start the wall. And that fight has not been started by gutless Republicans who refuse to do in the past. That's why I'm kind of done with the party. I'd rather just register as a conservative these days. Really, it's really irritating. Sorry. I'm making a rant. Listen, I'm (inaudible). I got to, you know, when you tell me you got to go, you got to go. Hey, comedian Kevin Hart hitting back hard against the internet mob he said tried to take him down. The big update on the Oscars controversy coming up next.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Kevin hart is speaking out in his first interview since the Oscars controversy. The comedian explaining to Ellen DeGeneres why he refused to give into the mob mentality and apologize again for homophobic tweets from over a decade ago.

utterances.speaker: KEVIN HART, COMEDIANL
utterances.sentences: This is stuff I have addressed. I have talked about this. This isn't new. I've addressed it. I've apologized for it. Now, the headlines are starting to change. The headlines are Kevin Hart refuses to apologize for homophobic tweets from the past. The word again was left out. To go through 40,000 tweets to get back to 2008, that's an attack. That's a malicious attack on my character. That's an attack to end me. Somebody has to take a stand against the "trolls." You have to!

utterances.speaker: ELLEN DEGENERES, SHOW HOST
utterances.sentences: Right, but they are going to win if you don't host the Oscars, you know.

utterances.speaker: DEGENERES
utterances.sentences: Then they win.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: So Greg, Ellen went on in that interview to actually effusively profusely praise him. I just split three words together there because it's a Friday, gave him a lot of praise and said he should host and she is obviously a leading voice in the LGBT community.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: LGBTQ, I think.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Jesse. You are so inclusive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Please be sensitive. Be sensitive. That's all I ask.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I like Kevin Hart. I think he's really funny. Do you think there is a chance he actually does host still?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think the bigger story here and we've talked about this a lot on this show, how envy on social media has wed itself to the exciting thrill of the hunt, the mob. We've talked about this with so many people.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So the consequence here, it's the fear of the backlash. It's not just the initial outrage. It's that Ellen is now facing a backlash and when you -- and how did I find this out? It was in the "Hollywood Reporter." It said that, "She is facing a backlash. No, it was just a handful of people on twitter."

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So the problem is the media, like The Hollywood Reporter, one of many, they elevate social media complaints as newsworthy. And they have a willing -- they have a willing accomplice. Corporations. So the corporations are terrified. When they find out, "Oh, my God. Something is bubbling up on Twitter," you better go on vacation for a few days. You better lighten up. And the problem is because we're reacting, we're allowing social media to decide what is good and what is bad. Forgiveness is impossible. No, you can't forgive anybody, because the mob never forgives. You make a mistake 10 years ago, there's a lot of lonely people out there who have the time and the effort to chase you down. It's pathetic! And I'm glad. When Ellen did that, that is immense progress; and everybody has to follow that lead.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I think what you're seeing in culture is the same thing you're seeing in politics. It's one side or the other. And once you're on the other side, you are fair game for everything, and that's when the mob is activated and justified to really squash someone. And what we're forgetting is social media goes through pretty quick evolutions. And Twitter and Facebook meant something very different in 2008, especially to comics, than it does now in 2018.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Because it hadn't been around very long. So people didn't realize that it would be used as a barometer and a road map to your dark soul. And that things that you might have said if you were working something out or things you might have said spontaneously that were tasteless, that you might have treated like passing conversation a decade ago, are now seen as being incredibly permanent. It also poses the challenge to parents, because we have to teach our kids, as they, you know, develop social media habits, that this stuff stays with you. And it's really --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Worse than a tattoo.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It is a very scary thing, because there's no Kat Von D makeup for tweet removal. And if you do take something off of social media, you look guilty.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And it gives more ammunition to the other side that is all too eager to end your career. And he's right about that. So I'll be curious to see where this whole thing ends up and if he does, in fact, host the Oscars.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: That's right. And I don't know, Dan, if you're -- you're very active on social media, I should say.

utterances.speaker: DAN BONGINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: You get into some Twitter dust-ups with people.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, you could say that.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I'm not on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Smart move.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: But that's what I hear. I'll be curious to see if the Academy actually backs down if Kevin Hart decides he wants to host. But how do you navigate these complicated issues online?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's tough. I think Greg nailed it, though. The Twitter era has elevated a couple of kids eating s'mores in Mama's basement and Crackerjacks, watching inappropriate videos, who tweet to corporations. I mean, you know who they are. We all know who they are in this business. It's about 5 or 10 guys who have highjacked about 1-- other accounts. Corporations and Hollywood people start to get scared, understandably so. But 10 years ago or 20 years ago this wasn't an issue. You'd e-mail a company. It would be from the same e-mail account over and over, and they'd largely ignore it. The problem is, though, Marie, this is going to have to be led by the left. Peggy Noonan has a great piece in the Wall Street Journal today. How this politically-correct society is starting to cannibalize itself. You're seeing it in Hollywood now. And we don't have, sadly, regretfully, the cultural power on the right to lead a revolution here. We just don't. We don't own the media. We don't own academia. The left has to lead this and say, "Guys --"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And they are. You know, a lot are leaving. You look at a lot of intellectuals that are moving --

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Gervais. Did you see his tweet about the comedy thing?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Listen, you don't like the comedy. Don't listen to the comedy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There needs to be more comedians, though. There needs to be more comedians. A lot of them are cowards.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: It also downplays real homophobia, real racism --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: -- when people really are saying things. Jesse, the last word on this is going to you. Have you ever tweeted something that --?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, never. He doesn't need Twitter for that.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: I'm an expert at apologies. I've been apologizing my whole life, and I've learned a few things. One, you always apologize in your personal life, and you never apologize in your professional life. When something happens in your professional life, people come to you and say, "You need to apologize," and then when you apologize, you look weak, you look insincere and then you look self-serving. All apologies do is embolden your enemies and embolden the media. And you say -- you write a little thing, these are the boundaries in which I'm allowed to play in, and you build your own prison for yourself. And when you apologize publicly, professionally, you're apologizing to a mob. And no one can accept the apology --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- so the apology is not actualized. It doesn't count.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what's funny, though? When you do apologize, somebody's going to be playing this back to you.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: It will be me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're right. You're right about it.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: It will be interesting to see. The Oscars still doesn't have a host. So maybe this could be a turning point and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: I nominate Greg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg's available.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm busy.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I think Ellen and Kevin Hart should host together.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Very good.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Maybe that's what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump and Barack Obama.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Because Ellen has hosted in the past and said that she called the Academy personally --

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Can you imagine that?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- to mend fences. So maybe that's exactly what's going to happen.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Put it on the table. OK. Ending the week, first week of 2019, insane lines, short tempers. How New Year's resolutions are creating chaos, up next.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: We're all making plans and scrapping them. Only 4 days into 2019. And chaos is already unfolding for many trying to make good on their New Year's resolutions. Some salad places here in New York City -- first-world problems -- and in Washington, D.C., are getting mobbed by insanely long lines, you guys. Frustrated customers reportedly shouting and cursing over the out-of- control wait times. And gyms right now, are jam-packed with people pledging to slim down in the New Year's. They get their biscuits on the treadmill for the first time in years. Others are joining in on Dry January, where they give up drinking alcohol for --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg. Greg.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Is is Dry January for you, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There's no such thing as a dry January. It might be a double-wet January.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dry Monday, Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I have a solution. Double the length of a year. Either by making the hours 120 minute long or a year 724 days, so you only have one Christmas. You only have one birthday, one wedding anniversary, one Thanksgiving, one Halloween. Think about how much thinner and richer you will be if you cut all this stuff in half. This is what -- time is so destructive. You could be good all year and then ruin it --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg -- Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- in the last couple of months.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is it like to have this constant pressure to be so creative every single segment?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Doesn't this make sense?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You don't have to have a brilliant idea every segment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a brilliant idea.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I think what he's doing is he's making up for the fact that he doesn't like resolutions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I haven't killed anyone yet this year.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: That's your resolution?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So far my resolution -- my resolution stands.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's only January.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: No heads in my trunk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No. Yet.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Very good. That's very big of you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I think it's funny, because you don't have to go to the gym to work out. And you don't have to go to Chop to get a salad, not that it's not a lovely salad place. Make your own damn food and bring it in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was at the gym the other day. It was empty. I was the only one. But my only resolution -- KENNEDY: Except it was 4 in the morning. That dedicated.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They was a park, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Why were you watching me in the park? You're going to kill me, aren't you?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Not yet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No. My only resolution was to write a book. And the only thing I've done about that was tell everybody I'm going to write a back.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Accountability.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I told "Hannity" about me writing a book last night, and then he gave me advice. I don't like the advice, and now it's annoying me. And it's making me think I have to change gears now, or I might just stick with my gut and do what I was going to do anyway.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And find a ghost writer?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: That's accountability. The best New Year's resolutions are ones that are -- ones that are specific and you can track. Not just "be nice" or "work out more" but "go to the gym five days a week" or whatever.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: OK, but here's -- here's what I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What was the advice?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm not telling you.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Everything --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Have a ghost writer, actually.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Everything happens so --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He said it has to be something of substance.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Don't do that. Go with your gut.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know! I'm going to go with my gut.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Substance. Yes, that's what everyone wants to read from your book, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Ouch.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: You should just call it "Substance," by Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's "Rising Watters," by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It could be "Shallow Watters."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to change that, by the way, or you'll be suing me for credit, if that's the name.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: "Muddy Watters"?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Muddy? My Dad's going to think --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Everything is so intense now that people want so much more, and they want it right away.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And they want the resolutions to be fixed and finished. And they want to be skinny.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: That's true. No, I think because in a month no one will be at the gym. I think New Year's is a good time to take stock of where you are to make some resolutions for the whole year. One I did last year that I'm doing again this year is read a book a month, at least.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, Dana.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: And so I know, but it's actually --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That would mean I'd have to cut back.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Do you read to your dog Jasper before bed, too?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: But that's one that continues throughout the year. Or I say I want to run a half-marathon in May.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow!

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: So it's like out -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Sign up for a race. Therefore, your fitness is about a goal.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It's not about how you look.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Listen, this is a rough time of the year.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: I love the people who make this commitment to fitness. It's great. It's healthy for you. Do your thing, OK? But I go to the gym every day. There are general rules in the gym. You don't curl in the squat rack. Ladies and gentlemen --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I hate that.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Look, don't curl in the squat rack.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And don't squat in the curl rack.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: And don't squat -- people try to do it. And if you don't know how to use a machine, please, I'm humbly begging you, ask someone. I've seen people like --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Ask Dan.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: What is this, a spine twister? And they get in there, and you're like -- you've got to rush to help them. So I love it that you're going to the gym. It's great. But this is the most dangerous time of the year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Don't you hate it when they -- but they take up a piece of equipment, and they have their phone and all their stuff there.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: And the towel. And the towel on the arm (ph) piece, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And they don't do anything.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Can I -- can I tell you something that happened to me in the gym recently?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Someone -- so when you go into the pool, there's the room --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sorry about that.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- there's a closet where they have the paddle boards. You should apologize.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know what it is.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: The paddle boards and the poll buoys. And I walked in, and the lifeguard walked in. And he said, "Ma'am, do you smell urine?" And I looked down, and someone had made a tinkle potty on the floor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yuck.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And it was so -- so offensive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You shouldn't work out where Kilmeade does.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Most people hide it in the pool. Right? Geez.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Well, we're just getting warmed up, believe it or not. Don't go anywhere. "Fan Mail Friday" is next. Woo!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Fan Mail Friday."

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Woo!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We're answering your questions. The first one is really good. From Sharon Campbell: "If you could follow someone all day, who would it be," Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'd follow you, Greg, because you work so hard. I have never met someone that works so hard, besides Kilmeade. You -- you do FOX Nation. You write columns. You write books. You have two shows. I think you have a body double.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Actually, you know, I just -- I don't -- maybe I should follow myself.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You aren't used to getting compliments, are you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Like I'm going, where's the insult?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: "How can I be funny?"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Where's the insult? I'm actually speechless. Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I would follow the president. I think it would be fascinating.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a good one.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Just to see the conversations that he has, but more importantly, the reaction to the previous conversation when that person leaves the Oval Office.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's when the leaks start.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I want to hear some of the comments that he makes. I want to see how he interacts with his family and with his staff. Because I think people have built this negative and positive mystique around him that is totally unsustainable. So I would like to see for a day how it actually works.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'll invite you to the White House one of these days. We'll knock it out.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Jesse, say hello (ph) to me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dan.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Michael Jordan.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Still?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Did I steal your --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: In 2018 -- 2019, Michael Jordan?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, just to ask what is it like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You'd be so annoying.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: -- to be such a cash money winner? Every -- I would. I would be, like, nipping at his heels the whole day. Every money shot he hit. I mean, this guy was the epitome of a winner. I would wear him -- his eardrums would be broken by the end of the day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. Marie.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I was going to say LeBron James.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Well, you know --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Which is similar, because --

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Michael is better. I know I'll get nasty tweets.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I'm going to -- I'm going to go back on Twitter just to tweet at you about that. Because I think LeBron is fascinating, in addition to obviously being amazing at basketball. He has this school, and he is a huge --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Anti-Semite?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: -- wine connoisseur.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now Greg's going to follow him.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: And, like, posts all about the amazing wines he drinks online. So I think that would be very fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know who I would follow, if I followed someone?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: A big controversy, him with the wine.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would follow Michael Moore, because he moves slow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't want to have to work too hard. I just -- I would just follow him.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And probably more naps.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly. It would be probably the easiest follow ever. What -- from Derr -- who cares who it's from right now?

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: dHermann1969.dh, "What's the most interesting thing you saw on the way to work today?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "What's the most interesting thing you saw on the way to work today," Dan.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's New York. So I live in Palm City now. I grew up in New York. And in Palm City, it would be very interesting. Up in New York, it was only interesting because I'm now from Palm City.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: It was a guy having a full-blown conversation with himself and answering. You know, I was walking with my daughter. So I kind of, like, inserted myself between the two. But he was answering himself in the conversation, and he was proud of himself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That was Donny Deutsch.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: He said, "I'm in it for the little guy." And the guy's like, "And I'm the little guy." And it was, like, really incredible how he answered himself so fluidly. But again, in New York it's probably not that unusual anymore. But it would be where I live.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I take the subway every day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It's an incredible sociological event and experiment every single day. And I saw a guy use all of his brute strength to hold the door open, because there were about 10 of us were sprinting for the train that we were bound to make.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's nice.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And the next one wasn't coming for eight minutes.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: That's nice.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And he held it open. And everyone ran on. And they were exasperated but so relieved at the same time. And it's these acts of kindness that always surprise me. And New Yorkers, if you're lost, they will always help you get to where you need to go.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, they're great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm. Even if it's not really where you're going.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It wasn't the train that I needed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're in a box under somebody's bed for three weeks. Which happened to me in the '80s.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I woke up in the hotel lobby in SoHo and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Marie.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I literally have nothing. I saw nothing interesting on the way to work. I stay a block from FOX when I'm in New York.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You saw me in the greenroom.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Without makeup.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: But it's unusual that something happens in that block. It is Times Square-ish, but --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: -- I've got nothing on this.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Marie came to my office today.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I saw Kennedy's office today, yes, because I'd stored my shoes and my wine there from last week.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Interesting. Jesse, what did you see?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I yelled at my shoeshine guy on the way to work.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: The one in Rockefeller?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are -- you are stereotypical.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Here's why. No, no, here's why.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: You have to apologize to him now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So I have a new shoeshine place I'm trying to break in. I haven't even gone there yet. I've gone there twice. Two weeks ago, I went to get a shine. And the guy says the guy that does the shines was late. OK? So strike 1. Today I go to get another shine. The guy says the guy that shines shoes is on vacation. And I'm like, "Wait, you shine shoes; you're taking a vacation? Get another guy to shine shoes."

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: This is very good for all of us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I go, "The next time I come in, there'd better be a guy to shine shoes." So I went to the best shoe shine place in Rock Center. They always do a nice job. Five bucks.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I've seen you getting your shoes shined there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: My shoes are so nice now. I'm never going to the place on Wall Street again.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Get a mirror and do it again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm never going to that place again.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Get a shine box.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a beautiful story. That's the most interesting thing I just saw, was you telling the shoe story. I had something else, but that won. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Time now for "One More Thing" -- Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, you know what tomorrow night is? It's "The Greg Gutfeld Show," 10 p.m., brand-new new episode. Emily Compagno, you love her. Larry Gatlin, music legend. Kat Timpf, Tyrus. That's Saturday, Jan. 5th, 10 p.m. Eastern Time. Watch it or you'll pay a price! Now it's time for this. GUTFELD (singing): Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And they are. They are great! Especially when you give them a little bath, like this little fella. Check him out. Come on. There he is. A little baby hedgehog getting a little bath. If that doesn't make your spine tickle, you're dead to me. Look at that! This is why -- GUTFELD (singing): Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I thought they killed that. All right. "Watters' World," 8 p.m., Saturday night, Eastern Time. We have Herman Cain, Mike Huckabee, Dean Cain. A lot of Cains on the show.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: A lot of Cains.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's the Cain show. We also have -- I don't know if you guys saw that, the Women's March, they canceled it in California, because there weren't enough white people marching. And we have the leader of that women's march to explain why they postponed it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Or not enough -- I thought it was the opposite.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Too many white people. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Too many white people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Too many white people. Watch the tease. Are we live? All right. Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Do it live. Exactly right, Jesse. This is actually great news for those who have seen family members and loved ones suffer from Alzheimer's. For the first time in 15 years, there may be a new Alzheimer's drug. It is a drinkable cocktail, and they have had profound results in mice. They are going to try it on humans very soon here. Not only could it cure Alzheimer's, it could also reverse some of the memory loss. And --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's another reason why animals are great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If it works on mice, it works on people.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: They are breeding mice that have a specific traits with Alzheimer's when they are introduced into their physiology, and they are responding very well to this. So this could be incredibly exciting, groundbreaking news, the first in over a decade and a half.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's great news. All right. Marie.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: So this weekend, 30 teams take to the snow as the annual Gunflint Mail Run Sled Dog Race takes place in Cook County, Minnesota. There are 12 classes in the race. Look at these dogs. They're amazing. Twelve-dog, 100-mile race. And an eight-dog, 65-miler. The race started in 1977, and as part as my mom's 70th birthday present, she is there with some of her friends. I think we have a photo of her. That's my mom, Jane Harf, with one of the dogs. The course goes through glacially-sculpted boreal forests, through an immense network of lakes and streams. It is beautiful. It is cold. It's very cool. Check it out. You can follow it online.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And they wear little shoes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: So I usually travel alone up here to New York from Florida, but I brought my daughters with me on this trip. They thought it would be funny to photobomb me outside the studio, especially my little one, making the most muscular pose, which is fantastic. So there. There is a picture. They were just out there before. But it was funny, because we traveled with all this luggage, and I found out one bag was exclusively stuffed animals for my youngest daughter. And I found this little schedule she drew on the hotel stationery, which is absolutely terrific. They have a picture of it. Morning, pee-pee, food, treat, pee. And I figure, these animals, these stuffed animals really have to go to the bathroom a lot. That's her writing. I did not make this up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Lou Dobbs does that for me. With the little chart.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is really cute.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you. It's the actual note. I'm going to treasure this forever.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I love it. Night time at the end.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Night time at the end. She had to throw that in there, too.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I love it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Very good.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Very responsible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is all for us tonight. We will see you back here on Monday, "Special Report" is up next with Bret Baier. Take it away.
